reviewText:
I didn't really expect much from this game, having seen many other games nowadays try so hard to pull off the Metroidvania style with a mediocre result.
That was far from the case on this game.

Attacking feels smooth and many other mechanics make the combat one of the most enjoyable in a 2D world. The story feels JRPG-ish with the way the dialogue is set up, which I personally find as a plus. The leveling system adds several different ways to go about fighting, as does the element system which allows for a combination and easy-swap to counter any monster type at any moment.

While the platforming can be difficult at times, its more than likely that it is for a completely optional item that may or may not help you. I see a lot of complaints regarding the platforming, but most of the difficult" ones are simply optional.

As far as progressing through the game
date: there is no hand holding. There is a simple indicator on which area you need to go to and the direction it's in. There is a lot of exploration to be done
recommended: especially later in the game when backtracking is essential to completing that old puzzle you didn't have the ability or means to complete before.\n\nWhat I have a minor issue with is the restricted trading system
hoursPlayed: as it sometimes feels like it doesn't give anything of use. There are obvious exceptions to this such as the weapon/armor upgrades given later in the game
voteText: but otherwise there are only a few other items that you will be looking for each time you find a trader.\n\nMy biggest issue though is the lack of "navigation completion". By that
helpfulPercent: I mean that the maps don't indicate very well that this particular room is complete
votesHelpful: giving the feeling that there's always Something left to do it there
votesTotal: when in reality there isn't. It's a little frustrating for the completionist in me because I want to be sure I collect every treasure and complete each room to its fullest.\n\nOverall
votesFunny: a must-get for anyone looking for a Good Metroidvania game. 9/10"
commentsCount: January 2, 2014

reviewText:
Similar to Metroidvanias: You acquire new abilities and items which encourage you to revisit old locations and open new areas.
Similar to RPGs: There is a leveling and character customization mechanic, gear and weaponry to acquire and buff, and companions to assist you.
Similar to DMC: There is a very fun but not overly complex melee / combo system. It's not hard to get the hang of, but adds some depth to otherwise simple, enjoyable swordplay.

Somehow, the game is so much more than the sum of its parts would suggest. Highly recommended.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText: I have spent a very large amount of time playing this game, and it's been worth every moment. This game, to me, has set the bar for what crowd funded indie games can achieve. It was a totally addicting journey from start to finish. I normally don't do metroidvania because I am conceptually against backtracking and it certainly didnt help that I havent been into platformers since maybe the late GBA era, but this game persisted to me as a stand out title. I love so much about the game, the music, the combat, the level of character customization (weapons, armor, accessories, meaningfully branched skill trees, etc.), the well implimented story and all the little details and encounters. It reminds me of Dark Souls in a more colorful way. Angels are trying to murder you (and everyone else) and harvest your souls, demons are trying to do essentially the same thing and you are here to sort that out with nothing but the simple goal of shredding two oppressive and militant Goddesses. I normally dont PC game all that much, so the controls were innitially kind of a brick wall to me, but I was enjoying the game so much that I found mysellf trying very hard on the first playthrough to actually adapt to using my fingers instead of my thumbs for playing the game (The game supports game pads, but apparently only Xbox because my PS3 controller wont work). I whole heartedly reccomend this game if you like RPGs, platforming, challenging gameplay and really inspired combat with a hint of DMC flair.

reviewText:
Valdis Story is a fun little Metroidvania style game, with a fairly solid combat and levelling system.
The visuals are incredibly pretty, and the music is decent as well (though not amazing).

The problem with this game is that it implements a few story branches that will majorly affect certain 'safe zones' getting cleared of NPCs. Often there is no clear way of knowing how your actions will or won't affect what happens later. Nothing is TOLD to you, you just have to get there by luck and a little bit of knowing what's going on.
Finding your way around can be a total pain as well. You have a map, but you can't switch the map to scan other zones for unexplored areas. You have to physically go to those zones to check for things you've missed.
The other problem is that the story is ultimately a little muddled and I'm not given any reason to truly care about any of the characters - not even the protagonist. There is nothing that makes anybody particularly memorable or loveable. They exist, and you can talk to them, but there's no reason to care about them. During the final moments of the game, a few characters even appear and 'assist' you in killing enemies, but there's no reason for their appearance and you can't talk to them. They feel like an afterthought thrown in to help serve the ending scenes.

It's a fun little game; it's not amazing, but it's pretty good.
voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
Valdis Story is a great example of metroidvania which, while incorporating all the elements perfectly still has something new to say. Exploring a 2D map while leveling up and gaining new abillities by defeating bossess isn't a new idea. By adding a few features Valdis Story gains its own character. These are : smooth, combo-based battle system with ranking and prizes based on your performance, actual connection between chosen skills, equipment, stats and even spells; and as of now 2 characters with vastly different playstyle.

The music and graphic are beautiful and really make you immersed in the underwater city. However the biggest thing is animation. In a game focused on fighting, jumping, avoiding and running the developers did a great job with bringing it to such high level.

For me the biggest downside was somewhat lacking transport system. The map is quite big and I believe that during the endgame more shortcuts should be made available. There are also some frustrating moments, which require you to really nail such a obscure mechanic like grabbing ledges.

The game is great, long, has a lot of secrets and offers great replayability. I believe it's really worth its value even without a discount.

reviewText:
All right. As angry as the puzzles can make me, as harrowing as some of these boss battles are, AS ♥♥♥♥♥♥ AS I CAN ♥♥♥♥ING GET AT THIS ♥♥♥♥ING GAME...

It is worth every dime you pay for it. Despite the challenges, or even because of the challenges if you can get past the possibilities of rage quitting, it is a wonderful game. The graphics are stunning, the mechanics of the game are pretty spiffy, the characters are pretty awesome, and the plot keeps me interested. The enemies are broad in variety, the bosses are a league of their own, and finding crew members is a fun side game of its own, I'd have to say.

The fact that your main character's soul can gain either a dark, light, or neutral affinity based on the armor you choose, the spells you use most often, and the accesories you choose to wear is pretty novel. Most games, it's what you choose to say. This game, it's how you choose to fight, and that is a rather cool idea, and at the very least, really ♥♥♥♥ing intriguing.

I would suggest this game to anybody. Especially if you love hacking and slashing, some witty one liners, using magic spells, and the occasional puzzle. I'll admit, as much as they ♥♥♥♥ me off, they provide an edge-of-your-seat challenge that tend to have this really relieving and rewarding feeling when you can manage to make it to your goal in time.

Definitely buy it. If you got 15 dollars, I would recommend this game. The replay value really speaks for itself, and you can play as one of a few characters, so hours of fun are something to be had with this game. So what are you waiting for? Dive into the Abyssal City! The gods aren't going to beat the ♥♥♥♥ out of themselves!

reviewText:
I'll start by saying this is a great game, the only thing that stops it being a fanstastic game though is some flaws which bleed through into frustration inducing headache.

It's your normal 'start with nothing but your sword' affair and then go to villages performing their run of the mill tasks 'please get me X item and i'll unlock this door for you' and so on and you run around dungeons with a different colour/environment with slightly different spikes/traps in each one. Rinse and repeat until bosses are killed, find some other people from your ship that sank to get extra shops, story and perhaps an attack or two and repeat the formula until the end.
There's no originality here but what it does, it does well.

The Soundtrack is magnificent, very impressive and gets the blood pumping in battle and sets a superb orchestral haze for general exploring. It's arguably some of the best 'fitting' music for a platform ARPG since Zelda 'A link to the past'.

Graphically and animation wise it's top notch, there's a few games in the same category which trump it but the style serves well and has a strong western anime feel to it.

Story wise? Again decent yarn, you are the grey line inbetween demons and angels and battle both. Done to death with diablo onwards but still its pretty interesting but not great.

So down to the meat of it:

Exploration? Check. There isn't a million rooms but my god the back tracking. I'll say it now, if you don't like backtracking in games, remembering where items/chests that are unreachable are and committing it to memory/paper or notepad then forget it. This is your personal hell. The map isn't that great and you can end up spending hours running through the same puzzles/traps/monsters etc just to find out which way is up and where you are meant to be going. Especially on the puzzles where you'll be force to run through the same ones several times.

Combat? Correct and present. It's not that complex, just rack up combos, block/dodge, rack up some more and so on. You get a nice dash feature called a skill cancel, it also allows you to break out of some frames of animation in a combat setting but generally speaking it's not that great and far too many puzzles expect it.
The worst bit about combat is the juggling that occurs on you. Too many opportunities to have 2/3 enemies which bounce you around like a basketball and it's unblockable/cancellable.
Thankfully it doesn't happen often but it's incredibly annoying getting pinged between them an no hope of escape.
There's also a nice limit break /rage feature called focus allowing you to special attack for a large amount of damage. Which most of the time you wont bother and will ignore it, mainly because its a key combo to turn on the rage and then another to execute a super attack. I think it's probably why I just disregarded it as with the split seconds you get an attack opportunity on bosses, it's more bother than worth trying when you can just heavy attack instead.

Puzzles/traps/chests? Yarp. None are difficult in working out what to do, many are painful in execution. You are talking pixels and split second timing on some puzzles to get that elusive chest which, 9/10 times is rubbish anyway. The movement of the character is wooly at times, often you can be stood on a switch graphically - but you aren't and need to scootch over a little to activate it. Same with jumping onto walls to grab them, the collision can be horrible on some of the later dungeon walls which are crumbly graphic wise but you are actually guessing where to jump to. Bad design here unfortunately.

Bosses? All here and as 'boss by numbers' as you'd expect. One is weak to magic. One is weak to fire. One is weak to melee. One is half the wall you have to break bits of and so on. You've killed all these ten times before in every other game.
Oh and don't forget the obligatory mini boss rush at the end of the game. None of them are standout though. After you've killed them all you won't remember them.

RPG skills/experience/talents? +1 to X skill gives more attack and so on. Standard stuff, max level 20 and 1 talent point per level and 3 different trees that are unlocked as you move through them at levels 5/10/15. Standard fare and apart from the guardian tree, they don't alter your character play through that much. It's nice and simple which means it's easy to get into and you can even redistribute at an NPC later in the game. I would have preferred that each tree was far more weird and wonderful towards the bottom rather a mundane 'some extra HP' or 'more magic damage'.


Overall I enjoyed it - a second play through or a third? I don't think so. Not in it's current state anyway.
Even with the unlocks for a second play through or even a different character or two, the frustrations of backtracking/collision and juggling really takes the shine of what could have been the makings of a classic.

It's clear the developers are going for a multi game story here so here's to hoping the 2nd builds on this.
Overall B-

reviewText:
In a field strongly crowded with mediocre platformers, Valdis Story delivers a fresh and formidable experience that rewrites the formula rather then just rehashing it. Challenging, Castlevania-esque gameplay rewards patience and practice while DMC style combo focused combat helps deliver not only a  gauge of your skill, but immedeate gratification when a new fight pattern is mastered.

There is challenge and replayability aplenty, as well. Follow the story, or go exploring. Certain areas may start off limits geographically, but there are plenty of challenging areas accessable right off the bat, whose only barrier to entry is your ability not to get killed.

Add this to a well written and unique story, snappy controls, a brilliant original soudtrack, and you wind up with a can't miss title.

voteText: No ratings yet

reviewText:
This is a combat-focused, combo oriented MetroidVania. It isn't entirely finished, but has a decent amount of replay value and was definitely worth the couple of playthroughs I've given it so far. It's a little on the easy side, but that seems typical of the genre. Last I checked there are two additional playable characters on the way, and I'll probably be playing through one more time with Reina, before they are released.

The combat system takes a little getting used to, and with a little attention can be used to create ridiculous combos and damage. That was actually one of my bigger problems, as most of the normal enemies died entirely too quickly to get a feel for the combat system. A few bosses in however, I'd figured out how to outmanuever enemies, essentially utilizing combat based-sequence breaking.

I spent a little bit of time backtracking, and the map isn't exactly enormous, but if you're any good at this sort of game you'll find it a cakewalk. And I have yet to try the game on any of the higher difficulties, so I figure my perception that the game is easy may be challenged later on.

Overall it's fun game with nice music, solid mechanics and decent replay value, and I'd recommend it to anyone interested in 2D platforming or dungeon crawling.

reviewText:
This game is very well done.

The art, combat, and music make up for a few of its frustrations.

Addressing some issues that other users have brought up:

No waypoints or journal - It is sometimes difficult to figure out where it is to go and I did manage to get stuck at one point, forcing me to reload the save. You will spend some time exporing.

Controls - The controls are a bit hard to master. I use a keyboard, and I imagine it would be slightly easier to use a joystick. It takes a bit of getting used to.

New armours - To receive new armour, you have to perform jumping challenges, where you must execute a series of jumps in perfect succession. Some of them are relatively simple, while others can be more than 10 jumps. This can get frustrating at times, but collecting all the armours is not required to complete the game.

As you defeat bosses, you will unlock new abilities to access new areas. Certain new abilities will make these jumping challenges easier. You can also return to old areas to completely loot it with new spells.

reviewText: Valdis Story is one of the best indie games I've played in quite some time. I backed it on Kickstarter and I'm glad I did. Some of the timed platforming puzzles/challenges can be grueling and leave absolutely no room for error but the most difficult ones are optional--the game never forces you into a timed puzzle you can't reasonably get out of with a couple of tries. Having said that, the rest of the game is great! The level design and story are fantastic, the character designs and animations are excellent, but the best, and maybe most surprising component of this game is Zack Parrish's soundtrack. If they make a sequel--and I hope they do--they should rehire that man and pay him double his asking price!
